revisions.rev:
{{ NCAATeamSeason | Mode = football | Year = 1968 | Team = Nebraska Cornhuskers | Logo = University-of-Nebraska-Lincoln-logo.svg | LogoSize = 59 | Image = | ImageSize = | ImageAlt = | Conference = Big Eight Conference | Division = | ShortConference = Big 8 | BCSRank = | CoachRank = | APRank = | Record = 6-4-0 | ConfRecord = 3-4-0 | WinsVacated = | WinsForfeited = | ConfWinsVacated = | ConfWinsForfeited = | HeadCoach = [[Bob Devaney]] | HCYear = 7th | OffCoach = | OCYear = | DefCoach = George Kelly | DCYear = | OScheme = | DScheme = | StadiumArena = [[Memorial Stadium, Lincoln|Memorial Stadium]] | Champion = | BowlTourney = | BowlTourneyResult = | ConfChamp = | ConfChampResult = }} {{1968 Big 8 football standings}} The '''1968 Nebraska Cornhuskers football team''' represented the [[University of Nebraska-Lincoln|University of Nebraska]] in the [[1968 college football season]]. The team was coached by [[Bob Devaney]] and played their home games in [[Memorial Stadium, Lincoln|Memorial Stadium]] in [[Lincoln, Nebraska|Lincoln]]. The Huskers were 6â4, but had a losing record in conference at 3â4. They lost three [[Big Eight Conference|Big 8]] games at home and were shut out 47â0 at Oklahoma in the season finale. Nebraska did not play in a [[bowl game]] for the second consecutive year; the next season without a bowl was 36 years later in [[2004 Nebraska Cornhuskers football team|2004]]. Following 1968, [[Tom Osborne]] was promoted to [[offensive coordinator]] and installed the [[I formation]] offense. This led to a 9â2 record in [[1969 Nebraska Cornhuskers football team|1969]] and consecutive undefeated [[NCAA Division I FBS National Football Championship|national championship]] seasons in [[1970 Nebraska Cornhuskers football team|1970]] and [[1971 Nebraska Cornhuskers football team|1971]]. ==Schedule== {{Cite web '''Ziegler, Mick''' #29 ''(Sr.)'' HB |- | colspan="5" valign="bottom" align="right" |       |} ==Coaching staff== {| class="wikitable" |- |align="left"|'''Name'''||align="left"|'''Title'''||align="center"|'''First year
in this position''' ||align="center"|'''Years at Nebraska''' ||align="left"|'''Alma Mater''' |- |'''[[Bob Devaney]]'''|||[[Head Coach]]||align="center"|1962||align="center"|1962-72||[[Alma College|Alma]] |- |'''[[Tom Osborne]]'''|||Offensive assistant||align="center"| ||align="center"|1964-97||[[Hastings College|Hastings]] |- |'''George Kelly'''|||[[Defensive Coordinator]]||align="center"|1960||align="center"|1960-68||[[University of Notre Dame|Notre Dame]] |- |'''Cletus Fischer'''|||Offensive Line||align="center"| ||align="center"|1960-85||[[University of NebraskaâLincoln|Nebraska]] |- |'''[[Carl Selmer]]'''|||Offensive Line||align="center"| ||align="center"|1962-72|| |- |'''Jim Ross'''||| ||align="center"| ||align="center"|1962-76|| |- |'''John Melton'''|||Tight Ends, Wingbacks||align="center"|1973||align="center"|1962-88||[[University of Wyoming|Wyoming]] |- |'''Mike Corgan'''|||Running Backs||align="center"|1962||align="center"|1962-82||[[University of Notre Dame|Notre Dame]] |- |'''[[Monte Kiffin]]'''||| ||align="center"| ||align="center"|1967-76||[[University of NebraskaâLincoln|Nebraska]] |} ==Game notes== ===Wyoming=== {{AFB game box start | Title = '''Wyoming at #14 Nebraska''' [box score] | Visitor = [[1968 Wyoming Cowboys football team|Wyoming]] | Host = '''#14 Nebraska''' | V1 = 10| V2 = 0| V3 = 0| V4 = 0 | H1 = 3| H2 = 0| H3 = 0| H4 = 10 | Date = 1968-09-14 | Location = [[Memorial Stadium, Lincoln|Memorial Stadium]], [[Lincoln, Nebraska]] | StartTime = | TimeZone = CST | Attendance = 66,922 }} {{AFB game box end}} At the end of the 1st quarter, Nebraska was trailing 3-10, and struggled to catch up for much of the game. Finally, five minutes into the 4th quarter, with the assistance of the [[Blackshirts (football)|Blackshirts]] who had held off any further scores from the [[1968 Wyoming Cowboys football team|Cowboys]], the Cornhuskers managed to get another touchdown to tie the game. Then, as time was running out and the Nebraska offensive effort was stalling, Nebraska PK Paul Rogers launched a 51-yard field goal through the uprights and into the stands for the win, leading to an exuberant mob of fans rushing the field in celebration. {{-}} ===Utah=== {{AFB game box start | Title = '''Utah at #14 Nebraska''' [box score] | Visitor = [[1968 Utah Utes football team|Utah]] | Host = '''#14 Nebraska''' | V1 = 0| V2 = 0| V3 = 0| V4 = 0 | H1 = 17| H2 = 7| H3 = 0| H4 = 7 | Date = 1968-09-21 | Location = [[Memorial Stadium, Lincoln|Memorial Stadium]], [[Lincoln, Nebraska]] | StartTime = | TimeZone = CST | Attendance = 66,198 }} {{AFB game box end}} The Cornhuskers tallied 518 yards of total offense while holding the Utes to just 138, 46 of which were on the ground, and had little trouble with Utah, holding them scoreless in Memorial Stadium. {{-}} ===Minnesota=== {{AFB game box start | Title = '''#9 Nebraska at #17 Minnesota''' [box score] | Visitor = '''#9 Nebraska''' | Host = #17 [[1968 Minnesota Golden Gophers football team|Minnesota]] | V1 = 0| V2 = 7| V3 = 0| V4 = 10 | H1 = 7| H2 = 7| H3 = 0| H4 = 0 | Date = 1968-09-28 | Location = [[Memorial Stadium (University of Minnesota)|Memorial Stadium]], [[Minneapolis|Minneapolis, Minnesota]] | StartTime = | TimeZone = CST | Attendance = 53,362 }} {{AFB game box end}} It seemed like a repeat of the first game of the year, as once again Nebraska started out behind and wasn't able to catch up again until the 4th quarter, and once again Nebraska PK Paul Rogers booted the game winning field goal at the end of the 4th quarter with just 1:32 remaining on the clock to secure the win against [[1967 Minnesota Golden Gophers football team|national co-champion]] [[1968 Minnesota Golden Gophers football team|Minnesota]]. {{-}} ===Kansas=== {{AFB game box start | Title = '''#6 Kansas at #9 Nebraska''' [box score] | Visitor = '''#6 {{cfb link|year=1968|school=University of Kansas|team=Kansas Jayhawks|title=Kansas}}''' | Host = #9 Nebraska | V1 = 0| V2 = 0| V3 = 9| V4 = 14 | H1 = 0| H2 = 6| H3 = 0| H4 = 7 | Date = 1968-10-12 | Location = [[Memorial Stadium, Lincoln|Memorial Stadium]], [[Lincoln, Nebraska]] | StartTime = | TimeZone = CST | Attendance = 68,128 }} {{AFB game box end}} The highly-regarded Kansas Jayhawks had been averaging 51 points per game, yet the [[Blackshirts (football)|Blackshirts]] managed to bottle them up to just 23 points, though Nebraska's 13 points were not enough to get the conference-opening win. Kansas managed to escape Lincoln with a victory only by scrambling to put up two touchdowns in the final 4 minutes. {{-}} ===Missouri=== {{AFB game box start | Title = '''#20 Missouri at #13 Nebraska''' [box score] | Visitor = '''#20 {{cfb link|year=1968|school=University of Missouri|team=Missouri Tigers|title=Missouri}}''' | Host = #13 Nebraska | V1 = 6| V2 = 10| V3 = 0| V4 = 0 | H1 = 7| H2 = 0| H3 = 7| H4 = 0 | Date = 1968-10-19 | Location = [[Memorial Stadium, Lincoln|Memorial Stadium]], [[Lincoln, Nebraska]] | StartTime = | TimeZone = CST | Attendance = 66,818 }} {{AFB game box end}} Nebraska was severely hampered by a day of mistakes, losing four fumbles, an interception, and suffering two punt receptions muffed and recovered by Missouri. Despite the tall odds presented by these burdens, the Cornhuskers dropped the game to the Tigers by only 2 points. {{-}} ===Oklahoma State=== {{AFB game box start | Title = '''Nebraska at Oklahoma State''' [box score] | Visitor = '''Nebraska''' | Host = {{cfb link|year=1968|school=Oklahoma State University-Stillwater|team=Oklahoma State Cowboys|title=Oklahoma State}} | V1 = 0| V2 = 0| V3 = 7| V4 = 14 | H1 = 0| H2 = 0| H3 = 14| H4 = 6 | Date = 1968-10-26 | Location = [[Boone Pickens Stadium|Lewis Field]], [[Stillwater, Oklahoma|Stillwater]], [[Oklahoma]] | StartTime = | TimeZone = CST | Attendance = 35,000 }} {{AFB game box end}} The first half was scoreless as both teams struggled unsuccessfully for an edge, but Oklahoma State found a way through and scored the first 14 in the 3rd. Nebraska fought back, and once again Cornhusker PK Paul Rogers scored the game-winner off his foot with PAT in the final minute to put Nebraska ahead by 1. {{-}} ===Iowa State=== {{AFB game box start | Title = '''Nebraska at Iowa State''' [box score] | Visitor = '''Nebraska''' | Host = {{cfb link|year=1968|school=Iowa State University|team=Iowa State Cyclones|title=Iowa State}} | V1 = 7| V2 = 14| V3 = 0| V4 = 3 | H1 = 0| H2 = 7| H3 = 0| H4 = 6 | Date = 1968-11-02 | Location = Clyde Williams Field, [[Ames, Iowa|Ames]], [[Iowa]] | StartTime = | TimeZone = CST | Attendance = 29,000 }} {{AFB game box end}} Iowa State helped to spot Nebraska with an early 14-0 lead by losing an early fumble and never recovered from the setback. The Cyclones made a feeble late attempt, coming within 8 points before the Cornhuskers put up another field goal to finish them off. {{-}} ===Kansas State=== {{AFB game box start | Title = '''Kansas State at Nebraska''' [box score] | Visitor = '''[[1968 Kansas State Wildcats football team|Kansas State]]''' | Host = Nebraska | V1 = 6| V2 = 0| V3 = 0| V4 = 6 | H1 = 0| H2 = 0| H3 = 0| H4 = 0 | Date = 1968-11-09 | Location = [[Memorial Stadium, Lincoln|Memorial Stadium]], [[Lincoln, Nebraska]] | StartTime = | TimeZone = CST | Attendance = 67,466 }} {{AFB game box end}} Nebraska was stunned at home, at their homecoming game, when Kansas State held the Cornhuskers to just 146 total yards, 78 on the ground, and slapped Nebraska with only their second shutout under Head Coach [[Bob Devaney]]. {{-}} ===Colorado=== {{AFB game box start | Title = '''Nebraska at Colorado''' [box score] | Visitor = '''Nebraska''' | Host = {{cfb link|year=1968|school=University of Colorado at Boulder|team=Colorado Buffaloes|title=Colorado}} | V1 = 12| V2 = 3| V3 = 7| V4 = 0 | H1 = 0| H2 = 0| H3 = 6| H4 = 0 | Date = 1968-11-16 | Location = [[Folsom Field]], [[Boulder, Colorado|Boulder]], [[Colorado]] | StartTime = | TimeZone = CST | Attendance = 48,327 }} {{AFB game box end}} Nebraska flashed with some vengeance in response to the previous week's shutout, running out ahead of Colorado in Boulder 22-0 with help from a 62 yard punt return touchdown, finally letting the Buffaloes on the board with just 2 minutes remaining to play. {{-}} ===Oklahoma=== {{AFB game box start | Title = '''Nebraska at #14 Oklahoma''' [box score] | Visitor = Nebraska | Host = '''#14 {{cfb link|year=1968|school=University of Oklahoma|team=Oklahoma Sooners|title=Oklahoma}}''' | V1 = 0| V2 = 0| V3 = 0| V4 = 0 | H1 = 7| H2 = 21| H3 = 0| H4 = 19 | Date = 1968-11-23 | Location = [[Gaylord Family Oklahoma Memorial Stadium|Oklahoma Memorial Stadium]], [[Norman, Oklahoma]] | StartTime = | TimeZone = CST | Attendance = 45,000 }} {{AFB game box end}} Oklahoma denied Nebraska's bid for a post-season bowl game, as the Sooners scored five touchdowns to set a new Big 8 record and handed NU its worst defeat of the [[Bob Devaney|Devaney]] era with a painful 47-0 shutout in Norman. {{-}} ==Rankings== {{See also|1968 NCAA Division I-A football rankings}} {| class="wikitable" style="white-space:nowrap;" |+ Ranking Movement |- !
